question: A) Under which conditions does the ET boundary in MODFLOW become active? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. ET occurs above the extinction depth — and fully at or above the ET surface.
error: ❌ Not quite. ET only occurs between the extinction depth and the ET surface.

question: B) How does increasing the extinction depth affect the ET–head relationship? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. Greater EXDP means a wider range of partial ET but doesn’t affect the maximum rate.
error: ❌ Check again. EXDP changes the shape and range of the curve — not the maximum rate.

question: C) What happens to actual ET if the groundwater head is below the extinction depth? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Below extinction depth, actual ET is zero by definition.
error: ❌ Not quite. ET is only active within the defined head range.

question: D) Which parameter directly controls the **maximum value** of groundwater ET losses in MODFLOW? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. EVTR defines the rate; cell area scales it to a volumetric loss.
error: ❌ EVTR and area define the peak loss. SURF and EXDP shape the domain.

question: E) What is the **role of SURF** (ET surface) in the MODFLOW EVT package? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Good! SURF sets the upper bound for full ET, not the rate itself.
error: ❌ SURF doesn’t define the rate — it defines where that rate applies.

question: F) Which scenarios would justify a large extinction depth in an ET boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. A larger EXDP reflects deeper root systems or longer capillary connections.
error: ❌ Only vegetation with access to deep groundwater justifies large EXDP.
